posts.name: Brandon McDonald
posts.cooked:
Hey everyone! I’m trying to create an autonomous path that backs up > shoots > starts intaking > backs up while intaking > stops intaking > goes forward > shoots.

Attached at the bottom is a screenshot of that path in the GUI and all relevant code as well as a link to our github.

Currently, when we run this auto it does this path. backs up > shoots > backs up > starts intaking > stops intaking > goes forward > shoots. We can not get it to back up and run the intake at the same time.

image 1918×1132 138 KB

image 1918×1132 138 KB

image 1918×1132 138 KB

Our Github!

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
A Parallel Deadline group runs multiple commands simultaneously and cancels the other commands when the first command finishes. Since you set the motors to 0 in your startIntake end function, you don’t have to have stopIntake command (though I generally prefer not to use end functions and just have the default command set motors to 0).

I’m a little confused by UnderBotSubsystem.this . Do you have all commands written as inner classes to your subsystem?

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: You may need a wait command after starting to intake so that it turns on before moving.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Brandon McDonald
posts.cooked:
Thank you! That’s exactly what I needed

Max_Morehead:

I’m a little confused by UnderBotSubsystem.this . Do you have all commands written as inner classes to your subsystem?

As a response to this… yes… It started as just a shoot and intake so it was easy to manage until it spiraled and now like all “great code” it is a 462 line monster.

posts.name: Brandon McDonald
posts.cooked: We want it to start when moving since it will be behind the note and needs to back up into it, thank you for the suggestion though!

reply_to_user.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
brandonmcd:

It started as just a shoot and intake so it was easy to manage until it spiraled and now like all “great code” it is a 462 line monster.

Yeah I wouldn’t do that, for this reason. What I’d recommend is passing subsystems as arguments to commands’ constructors. This pattern is called dependency injection , if you’re interested.

Better yet for the students on your team next year, learn the inline functional style that wpilib now recommends: Commands — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Brandon McDonald
posts.cooked: Luckily i’m familiar with WpiLib commands and if you check Our Github you can see a couple there. Our comp is tomorrow so I don’t have time to redo everything before then but it is something I plan to do in the offseason

data.fancy_title: How to make Pathplanner run a NamedCommand while moving?
data.title: How to make Pathplanner run a NamedCommand while moving?

accepted_answer.excerpt:
Sequential Group(
  backupToLine,
  shootCommand,
  Parallel Deadline Group(
    intakeNote (path),
    startIntake
  ),
  returnToLineFromIntake,
  shootCommand
)

A Parallel Deadline group runs multiple commands simultaneously and cancels the other commands when the first command finishes. Since y…
